post.description: Get a credit card detials input iframe (URL) for the consumer. This API is rate limited to 10 requests per minute per shopper id.

parameters.name: Content-Type
parameters.description: The MIME type of the body of the request.

parameters.name: X-Api-Key
parameters.description: The API key for the request. The API keys (non-prod/prod) will be supplied by the Digital Pay team.

parameters.name: X-Auth-Key
parameters.description: (Deprecated) You are required to use this header to provide the base64 encoded API key. Requires the X-Auth-Digest header to be present.

parameters.name: X-Auth-Digest
parameters.description: (Deprecated) You are required to use this header to provide the encrypted API key. The value is the API key encrypted with the client secret key. Requires the X-Auth-Key header to be present.

parameters.name: X-Message-Id
parameters.description: This id is used to keep track of the request and its response in the Digital Pay platform. If no value is provided for the request header, Apigee will auto generate an id to use for the request. This header will also be returned in the response and will have the value passed in (or auto generated) from the request.

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description: The Bearer token for the request. The Bearer token authentication approach can be used by API consumers that implement a client-to-server architecture (mobile app, browser site/page) or server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.) for calling Digital Pay APIs. However the Bearer token for a shopper/customer must be obtained from the IDM Server Token API which can only be accessed from a server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.). The Authorization header is only required if the X-JWS-Signature header is not present.

parameters.name: X-JWS-Signature
parameters.description: The JWS signature used to sign the request. The JWS signature authentication approach can only be used by API consumers that implement a server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.) for calling the Digital Pay APIs. The RSA private key, required to generate the signiture, has to be stored securely and should not be publicly accessible. The X-JWS-Signature header is only required if the Authorization header is not present.

parameters.name: X-Everyday-Pay-Wallet
parameters.description: A flag to indicate if the Everyday Pay wallet should be used when processing the API request. Set the header value to "true" to use the Everyday Pay wallet. Set the header value to "false" or exclude the header completely to use the default merchant wallet.

400.description: Missing or invalid request payload or value.

401.description: Invalid API Key or API Product Match Not Found or Invalid Token or Expired Token.

parameters.name: Authorization
parameters.description: The Bearer token for the request. The Bearer token authentication approach can be used by API consumers that implement a client-to-server architecture (mobile app, browser site/page) or server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.) for calling Digital Pay APIs. However the Bearer token for a shopper/customer must be obtained from the IDM Server Token API which can only be accessed from a server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.). The Authorization header is only required if the X-JWS-Signature header is not present.

parameters.name: X-JWS-Signature
parameters.description: The JWS signature used to sign the request. The JWS signature authentication approach can only be used by API consumers that implement a server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.) for calling the Digital Pay APIs. The RSA private key, required to generate the signiture, has to be stored securely and should not be publicly accessible. The X-JWS-Signature header is only required if the Authorization header is not present.

parameters.name: Authorization

The Bearer token authentication approach can be used by API consumers that implement a client-to-server architecture (mobile app, browser site/page) or server-to-server architecture (BFF, microservice, web server, etc.) for calling Digital Pay APIs. stepUpToken.description: The step-up token is used to track additional credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) attached to the payment instrument. It's only valid for a predefined time and if an expired step-up token is used during payment, the payment for that instrument will fail and the user will have to get a new step-up token before retrying the payment. A step-up token is returned in the response of a credit card iframe. This property is currently only required for credit card instruments and only if specific credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) is required during payment.

allowed.description: A flag to indicate if the merchant profile in the container allows the use of this payment agreement.

paymentInstrumentId.description: The payment agreement payment instrument id that will be used for the charges.

cardSuffix.description: The suffix (last 4 digits) of the credit card number.

expiryMonth.description: The month of the expiry date of the credit card.

expiryYear.description: The year of the expiry date of the credit card.

startDate.description: The payment agreement start date and time. The timestamp format is ISO8601.

endDate.description: The payment agreement end date and time. The timestamp format is ISO8601.

chargeAmount.description: The amount that will be charged at the frequency specified in the payment agreement.

expired.description: A flag to indicate if the payment agreement is expired.

updateURL.description: The URL of the endpoint to use to update the payment agreement.

type.description: The type of the step up action. For payment agreements this will be CAPTURE_CVV which identifies that the consumer must capture the CVV prior to payment.

mandatory.description: A flag to indicate if this step up (action) is mandatory.

url.description: The URL of an iframe. This iframe is used to capture a credit card expiry and CVV or CVV only. The URL will automatically switch between expiry and CVV or CVV only endpoints based on the container requirement.

allowed.description: A flag to indicate if the merchant profile in the container allows the use of this payment instrument.

creditCard.description: The container transaction type to use for credit card instruments. This property is only required if the payments request contains credit card instruments.

giftCard.description: The container transaction type to use for gift card instruments. This property is only required if the payments request contains gift card instruments.

payPal.description: The container transaction type to use for paypal instruments. This property is only required if the payments request contains paypal instruments. Only PURCHASE is currently supported for paypal instruments.

creditCard.description: The container transaction type to use for google pay credit card instruments.

debitCard.description: The container transaction type to use for google pay debit card instruments. Only PURCHASE is currently supported for google pay debit card instruments.

googlePay.description: This object is only required if the payments request contains google pay instruments.

creditCard.description: The container transaction type to use for apple pay credit card instruments.

debitCard.description: The container transaction type to use for apple pay debit card instruments. Only PURCHASE is currently supported for apple pay debit card instruments.

applePay.description: This object is only required if the payments request contains apple pay instruments.

clientReference.description: A merchant application specific reference number. This number should uniquely identify the transaction in the merchants system.

orderNumber.description: The merchant order number of the transaction.

stateOrTerritory.description: The recipient's abbreviated state or territory.

countryCode.description: The recipient's Alpha-2 (2-character) ISO-3166-1 country code.

shippingAddress.description: This object is only required if the payments request contains paypal instruments.

paymentInstrumentId.description: The payment instrument id from the card capture iframe response or the list payment instruments response. This property can be omitted if the payment token property is present.

paymentToken.description: The payment token from the card capture iframe response or the list payment instruments response. This property can be omitted if the payment instrument id property is present.

amount.description: The amount you want to pay with the payment instrument.

stepUpToken.description: The step-up token is used to track additional credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) attached to the payment instrument. It's only valid for a predefined time and if an expired step-up token is used during payment, the payment for that instrument will fail and the user will have to get a new step-up token before retrying the payment. A step-up token is returned in the response of a credit card iframe. This property is currently only required for credit card instruments and only if specific credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) is required during payment.

passcode.description: The passcode is used to send additional information (eg. gift card PIN) for the payment instrument. This property is currently only required for gift card instruments and only if the gift card PIN is required during payment. This property should NOT be used with credit card instruments (see stepUpToken).

extendedMerchantData.description: This object is only required if the payments request contains paypal instruments.

field.description: The name of the extended merchant data field.

value.description: The value of the extended merchant data field.

storeId.description: The in-store payment transaction store id.

rrn.description: The in-store payment transaction store id. This is a 12 digit "0" [zero] padded numeric string.

transactionTimestamp.description: The in-store payment transaction timestamp. The timestamp format is milliseconds since epoch.

storeData.description: This object is only required if the payments request is for an in-store (R10) payment transaction.

responseFormat.description: The fraud check response message format.

fraudPayload.description: Set to null to skip the cybersource fraud check.

clientReference.description: A merchant application specific reference number. This number should uniquely identify the transaction in the merchants system.

customerRef.description: A merchant application specific reference number. This number should uniquely identify the customer in the merchants system.

orderNumber.description: The merchant order number of the transaction. This property is only required if the 'immediateCharge' property is true.

stateOrTerritory.description: The customer's abbreviated state or territory.

countryCode.description: The customer's Alpha-2 (2-character) ISO-3166-1 country code.

paymentInstrumentId.description: The payment agreement payment instrument id that will be used for the charges.

startDate.description: The payment agreement start date and time. The timestamp format is ISO8601.

endDate.description: The payment agreement end date and time. The timestamp format is ISO8601.

chargeAmount.description: The amount that will be charged at the frequency specified in the payment agreement.

immediateCharge.description: A flag to indicate if a charge transaction must be performed at the time of payment agreement creation. This in convenient in the cases where a customer wants to process a first charge transaction immediately at payment agreement creation.

stepUpToken.description: The step-up token is used to track additional credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) attached to the payment instrument. It's only valid for a predefined time and if an expired step-up token is used during validation, the validation of that instrument will fail and the user will have to get a new step-up token before retrying the API call. A step-up token is returned in the response of a credit card iframe. This property is only required for credit card instruments and only if specific credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) is required during the API call.

responseFormat.description: The fraud check response message format.

fraudPayload.description: Set to null to skip the fraud check.

clientReference.description: A merchant application specific reference number. This number should uniquely identify the transaction in the merchants system.

customerRef.description: A merchant application specific reference number. This number should uniquely identify the customer in the merchants system.

stateOrTerritory.description: The customer's abbreviated state or territory.

stepUpToken.description: The step-up token is used to track additional credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) attached to the payment instrument. It's only valid for a predefined time and if an expired step-up token is used during validation, the validation of that instrument will fail and the user will have to get a new step-up token before retrying the API call. A step-up token is returned in the response of a credit card iframe. This property is only required for credit card instruments and only if specific credit card information (eg. CVV and expiry) is required during the API call. Only required if the payment agreement payment instrument id is being changed to a different payment instrument.
